cyclone.name: IAN
cyclone.current_location: about 220 mi SSE of Grand Cayman
cyclone.trajectory: Forecast to turn northwest tonight, then north-northwest Monday and north Tuesday, moving across western Cuba, entering the southeast Gulf of Mexico, and approaching Florida’s west-central coast mid-week
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: west-central Florida coast (near the Sarasota–Tampa area)

weather_observation.watch_coast: Lower Florida Keys from Seven Mile Bridge southward to Key West, including the Dry Tortugas
weather_observation.warning_coast: Grand Cayman and the Cuban provinces of Isla de Juventud, Pinar del Rio, and Artemisa under Hurricane Warning; La Habana, Mayabeque, and Matanzas under Tropical Storm Warning
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Western Cuba, Cayman Islands, Florida peninsula (greatest risk along the west coast but impacts possible across all of South and Central Florida)
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force wind gusts are possible Tuesday night through Wednesday with a peak 34-kt (39-mph) probability of 28%. Sustained tropical-storm winds are not certain but cannot be ruled out.
weather_observation.storm_surge: No significant storm-surge inundation expected on the Atlantic side of South Florida (guidance shows 1–3 ft confined to Florida Bay/Keys, not Port Everglades).
weather_observation.rainfall: 2–4 inches with isolated amounts up to 6 inches possible Monday through Wednesday; urban and flash flooding risk for Broward County coastal areas.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Dangerous surf and rip currents beginning early this week; port operations may also be affected by squalls and reduced visibility.
